title: Ostensive Communication: Its Creation, Evolution, and Stability
abstractText:
Communication is a fundamental component of human life and society. Most of our communication is ostensive. Ostension is the difference between a pointed finger that is a by-product of looking at your watch, and a pointed finger that is designed to direct someone's attention.

Our capacity for ostension means that any behaviour has the potential to be used in a communicative way. Indeed, much human communication is ostensive. It provides the foundation for many human institutions, including both language and culture. It appears to be species-unique, and it has clear evolutionary advantages. Despite this, many basic empirical questions about it are unaddressed. The Future Leaders scheme  will be used to experimentally investigate a range of fundamental questions about how ostensive communication systems operate. Specifically:

  • what general qualities distinguish ostensive behaviour from otherwise similar behaviour (eg the pointing example - what distinguishes the two different points?)
  • how ostensive communication systems evolve, and hence develop conventional forms
  • what keeps human ostensive communication evolutionarily stable.

The findings of this empirical work will be applied to current debates about the origins and evolution of human language.
findingsText: This grant is focused on the academic importance of human ostensive communication. Research is ongoing, but has already led to several important publications, including a book that has already been hailed as &quot;the most important and the best book ever written on the evolution of language&quot;. My research concerns a topic of inherent public interest - what makes us human? - and as such is amenable to public science communication. I have begun to pursue such opportunities. For instance, I will be speaking at the Edinburgh International Science Festival, in April 2015. Other
